_header: For thought constraint and grievous heaviness
Note:
Ringler Jr. (1992)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler , TM 426; Ringler Jr. (1988)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse Printed 1476-1558. London: Mansell, 1988, TP 434.5; for further extracts occurring separately cf. 4417; transcription of extract (6 lines) by Ashmole is Oxford, Bodleian Library Ashmole 53 (SC 6937), f. 81v (‘And vppermore depeint men might se / How with her Ring goodli Cana…And how her Brother so oft holpen was / In his myschefe bi the stede of Bras’ with the title, ‘Temple of Glass’).
_description:
John Lydgate, The
Temple of Glas — 1403 lines in couplets and rhyme royal stanzas

Bod638.First Lines:
For thoght constrynt & grevous heuynesseffor pensifhed &
                    for high distresse…
Bod638.Last Lines:
…I mene that benigne & goodly of hir faceNow go thi wey
                    & put the in hir grace
Bod638.Attributed Title:
The Temple of Bras (f. 16v and RT); Explicit The Temple of Bras
                    (f. 38)
Bod638.Facsimiles:
Robinson,  Pamela. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Manuscript Bodley 638: A Facsimile.
         Norman, OK: Pilgrim, and Woodbridge: Boydell and Brewer, 1982.

BodFair16.First Lines:
FOr thoght constreynt and grevous hevynesseffor pensyfhede and for
                    high distresse…
BodFair16.Last Lines:
…I mene the benigne and goodly of hir facenow go thy way and
                    put the in hir grace
BodFair16.Attributed Title:
The temple of Bras [crossed out with ‘glas’ added over by
                    Stowe, then ‘Glas’ added below by another hand imitating medieval
                    style] (f. 63); The temple of Bras (RT); Explicit the temple of Bras (f.
                        82v)
BodFair16.Facsimiles:
Norton-Smith,  John. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Bodleian Library MS Fairfax 16.
         London: Scolar Press, 1979.

BodTan346.First Lines:
For thouȝt constrenit and greuous heuinesffor pensifhede and
                    for heiȝ distres…
BodTan346.Last Lines:
…I ene þat benygne & goodli of hir faceNou go þi
                    way & put þe in hir grace
BodTan346.Facsimiles:
Robinson,  Pamela. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Manuscript Tanner 346: A Facsimile.
         Norman, OK: Pilgrim, and Woodbridge: Boydell and Brewer, 1980.
BodTan346.Editions:
Schick,  Josef,
                        ed.  
             Lydgate’s Temple of Glas.
EETS
         e.s. 60 (1891); repr. 1987. 
Norton-Smith,  John. 
             John Lydgate: Poems.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1966: 67.
Mitchell,  Allan J.,
                        ed.  
             The Temple of Glas.
         Kalamazoo, MI: Western Michigan University for TEAMS, 2007.

CULGg427.First Lines:
For thoght compleynt & greuous heuynesseffor pensyfhod &
                    for heigh distresse…
CULGg427.Last Lines:
…ffor loue of whom so as I can endyteI purpose here to makyn
                    & to write
CULGg427.Attributed Title: Here begynyth the temple of Glas (f. 490v)
CULGg427.Facsimiles:
Parkes,  Malcolm B.,  and  Richard Beadle.  
             “Introduction.” 
             Poetical Works. Geoffrey Chaucer. A Facsimile of Cambridge University
                Library MS Gg.4.27. 3 vols Cambridge: D. S. Brewer, 1979 (vol. 1); 1980 (vols. 2-3).

CamMagPep2006.First Lines:
[F]or thought constrent and grewous heuynesffor pensifhed and for
                    he distresse…
CamMagPep2006.Last Lines:
…I mene that benigne and godely of hir faceNow goo thy wey and
                    put the in hir grace
CamMagPep2006.Attributed Title: Temple of glas (added sixteenth to seventeenth centuries, p. 17)
CamMagPep2006.Facsimiles:
Edwards,  A. S. G. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Manuscript Pepys 2006: A Facsimile. Magdalen College,
                Cambridge.
         Norman, OK: Pilgrim, and [Woodbridge, Suffolk]: Boydell and Brewer,
            1985.

BLAdd16165.First Lines:
For thought compleynt and greuous hevynesseffor penfysshed and for
                    hye distresse…
BLAdd16165.Last Lines:
…ffor love of whame so as I kan endyteI pourpose here to maken
                    and to wtyte
BLAdd16165.Note:
Immediately followed by 275
                    without a break.
BLAdd16165.Attributed Title:
Et ensy fine vn petit abstraite appellez regula sacerdotalis et comence
                        vne soynge moult plesaunt fait a la request dun amoreux per Lidegate le
                        Moygne de Bury (f. 206v); þe dreeme of a trewe lover
                    made by daun John of þe tempull of glasse þat shall next folowe
                    þe hous of fame (RT, ff. 206v-207)

BLAdd38179.First Lines:
For thought constrent and grewous hevynessFor penfishode & for
                    he distresse…
BLAdd38179.Last Lines:
…I mene that benigne and godely of hire faceNow goo thy wey ad
                    put the in hir Grace
BLAdd38179.Note:
Note states this is from Samuel Pepys’ manuscript of
                    Chaucer’s fragments (f. 2).

BLSl1212.First Lines:
…how philomene yn to a nyȝtyngaleI turned was and Prowne
                    in to a swalowAnd how salyuse in hir maner halowThe feste of lucras
                    ȝet in Rome town…
BLSl1212.Last Lines:
…Dyscure yn opyn lest þei were refusedAnd some for
                    vantynges also were accused…
BLSl1212.Note:
Extract: lines 98-162. Catchphrase on f. 2v: ‘And other
                    eke’.
BLSl1212.Editions:
Norton-Smith,  John. 
             John Lydgate: Poems.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1966: 67-112.

Longleat258.First Lines:
[F]or thought constraint and greuous hevynesseffor pensitude and
                    high distresse…
Longleat258.Last Lines:
…O mene that benigne and goodly of hir faceNowe goo thy wey
                    and put the in hir grace
Longleat258.Attributed Title: Here endith the Temple of Glas (f. 32)
